passage.text: Development of a Ct equation taking into consideration the effect of lot variability on the inactivation of Cryptosporidium parvum oocysts with ozone
Relevant resource
True|False
Abstract

Cryptosporidium parvum oocysts are prevalent in surface water and ground water under the influence of surface water, and are difficult to inactivate using free chlorine, the most common disinfectant currently used for treating drinking water. In contrast, it has been shown that ozone is a more effective disinfectant than chlorine. US EPA is currently evaluating a treatment rule, which addresses the control of C. parvum oocysts in drinking water. The use of Ct (average disinfectant concentration multiplied by characteristic contact time) values is being considered as one of the options for demonstrating adequate control of this microbial contaminant. The purpose of this study is to incorporate the variability in inactivation kinetics among different lots of oocysts and to develop a statistical model for Ct based on first-order delayed Chick–Watson inactivation kinetics. A Bayesian approach is used to estimate the delayed Chick–Watson kinetic parameters. A log-linear regression analysis is then used to represent the effect of temperature on the resulting kinetic parameters. The overall model developed in this study provides an approach for water utilities and regulatory agencies to decide on the level of safety needed when developing treatment requirements for the inactivation of C. parvum oocysts with ozone as part of broader risk assessment considerations.

keywords
['Bayesian model', 'Inactivation', 'Lag phase', 'Lot variability', 'Rate constant', 'Safety factor', '1']
Introduction

Cryptosporidium parvum oocysts are microbial contaminants prevalent in surface water, as well as in ground water under the influence of surface water, that are difficult to inactivate with free and combined chlorine, the most common drinking water disinfectants currently in use throughout the world. In contrast, ozone has been shown to be a more effective disinfectant for controlling this protozoan parasite. Accordingly, the US Environmental Protection Agency is currently evaluating new minimum Ct (i.e., the product of average disinfectant concentration and characteristic contact time) requirements for the control of C. parvum oocysts with ozone. Inactivation data analyses ( ; ; ) performed in support of these efforts have been based on the recently demonstrated validity of the Ct concept for C. parvum oocyst inactivation ( ). The Ct concept states that the inactivation efficiency achieved at a certain Ct is independent of the concentration of the disinfectant, ozone in the present case, used. and performed statistical analyses with a limited number of data sets ( ; ; ; ), and although their approach was consistent with the Ct concept, they did not take into consideration the occurrence of an initial lag phase Ct (i.e., Ctlag) during which little or no inactivation takes place. However, recent studies ( ; ; ; ; ) have shown that the inactivation kinetics of C. parvum oocysts with ozone is typically characterized by an initial lag phase followed by post-lag phase of pseudo-first-order inactivation, consistent with the delayed Chick–Watson kinetic model ( ). Both of these phases have been found to be consistent with the Ct concept ( ). reanalyzed the data of using a Bayesian approach to determine the extent of the lag phase and the rate constant for the post-lag phase of inactivation with the aid of a Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) computational method ( ; ; ). However, a comparison of the various data sets now available in the literature ( ; ; ; ; ) for the inactivation of C. parvum oocysts with ozone have revealed that both the lag phase Ct and the post-lag phase inactivation rate vary from oocyst lot to oocyst lot even when using the same strain of C. parvum, and when following the same oocyst propagation, stock preparation and viability methods. Consequently, there is a need to characterize this variability and to assess the necessity of taking it into consideration when developing Ct requirements. The main goal of this study is to develop a Ct equation incorporating the effect of variability among different lots of C. parvum oocysts in the inactivation kinetics of this microbial contaminant with ozone. Data sets reported in the literature are first analyzed with a Bayesian approach ( ) with the goal of estimating the lag phase Ct, and the post-lag phase rate constant. Two separate mixed linear models are subsequently used to characterize the effects of pH, temperature (T), viability method and oocyst lot on the lag phase Ct and the post-lag phase inactivation rate constant. 1.1
Description of data sets

The data sets analyzed in this study and their corresponding experimental conditions are summarized in . , , and performed the experiments with buffered synthetic solutions in a semi-batch reactor, and determined oocyst viability by a modified in vitro excystation method. also performed their experiments with buffered synthetic solutions and using a semi-batch reactor, but they used split samples to determine oocyst viability by both modified in vitro excystation and animal infectivity assays. The data reported by was obtained with buffered synthetic solutions in a batch reactor, and the viability of the oocysts was determined by an animal infectivity method. The experiments by were performed with unspecified water in a semi-batch reactor, and the oocyst viability was determined by cell culture/RT-PCR assay. An additional factor that might affect inactivation kinetics is the strain of C. parvum used. Unfortunately, except for the work by , all other studies have been performed with oocysts of the Iowa strain and thus such effect could not be presently assessed. 1.2
Estimation of delayed chick–watson model parameters

A Bayesian change point analysis method is used to estimate the two parameters of the delayed Chick–Watson model expression, i.e., the lag phase Ct (Ctlag) and the post-lag phase inactivation rate constant (k), following the procedures described by . For a given set of n data points, the delayed Chick–Watson model with random measurement error is given by (1) Yi=ln(Nt/N0)i=μi+εi,i=1,...,n, where μi=0if(Ct)i⩽Ctlag=-k[(Ct)i-Ctlag]if(Ct)i>Ctlag, εi is the error term with mean 0 and variance σ2, and μi is the mean log inactivation. As part of the Bayesian analysis, prior knowledge of the state of nature is presented by specifying a prior distribution. A diffuse normal prior with mean 0 and variance 106 is used for k(k>0). No appreciable difference was seen in the posterior distribution of k for larger values of the variance parameter. We use a diffuse Inverse-Gamma (0.001, 0.001) prior for σ2, which is an approximation to the commonly used Jeffrey's prior pr(σ2)∝1/σ2. As Ctlag could be anywhere in the range of the Ct values of a given data set, a uniform prior is assumed for Ctlag between 0 and the maximum Ct value, Ctmax, of the data set. Smaller values for the parameters of the Inverse-Gamma prior did not influence the estimates of the model parameters. Moreover, a proper uniform (0.01,100) prior was used for σ2 (which covers the range of data variance) to evaluate the robustness of the results. No apparent difference was seen in the posterior distributions of the model parameters. Values for the parameters εi in Eq. are independent and identically distributed normal random variables with mean 0 and variance σ2. Thus Yi values are all independent normal random variables with mean μi and variance σ2. According to Bayes theorem, the posterior distribution of model parameters k, Ctlag and σ2 given the data y1, ..., yn is proportional to the product of the normal densities (or likelihood) of all Yi values evaluated at y1, ..., yn (given μi, σ2) and prior distributions of these parameters. This posterior distribution is used to estimate k and Ctlag for each experimental set. The MCMC method is employed using the BUGS software ( http://www.mrc-bsu.cam.ac.uk/bugs ) to obtain the posterior distributions of model parameters. The data for the inactivation kinetics of C. parvum oocysts with ozone presented by , , , , as well as the results by for which these authors provided oocyst lot information are used to estimate k and Ctlag for each experimental condition (either an experimental set or a group of experimental sets performed under the same conditions). Data sets for which oocyst viability was determined by the modified in vitro excystation method but without correcting for the viability of the control were corrected accordingly so that Nt/N0=1 at Ct=0 for all data sets. Initial analysis of the data sets revealed that scatter plots of the estimated k and Ctlag against corresponding pH values did not show any trend. This was consistent with the observation in recent studies ( ; ) that the inactivation kinetics of C. parvum oocysts with ozone was independent of pH. In contrast, both k and Ctlag were found to vary with temperature as shown in respective . As depicted in these figures, the estimated k and Ctlag values were found to obey an Arrhenius relationship. Furthermore, the scatter plot of the residuals from the log-linear regression analyses showed no significant correlation between the two residuals (p=0.36). Moreover, the bivariate analysis of covariance of k and Ctlag against 1/T also showed no significant correlation between the two dependent variables (p=0.31). Therefore, it was concluded that it would be appropriate to model the temperature dependence k and Ctlag separately. 1.3
Log-linear regression analysis using heterogeneous error variances

Estimated k and Ctlag values are subject to errors with heterogeneous variances that will be accounted for in a model relating each of k and Ctlag with temperature via Arrhenius relationship. In order to allow for the intercept parameter to vary between oocyst lots and for possible differences between the two viability methods (excystation and animal infectivity), we use the following mixed models: (2) ln(k)ijp=ap+bp(1/T)ijp+γjp+e1ijp,j=1,...,m,p=1,2, (3) ln(Ctlag)ijp=cp+dp(1/T)ijp+δjp+e2ijp,j=1,...,m,p=1,2. In Eqs. , ln(k)ijp and ln(Ctlag)ijp are the respective natural log transformed values of the post-lag phase rate constant and lag phase Ct for the ith data set, jth oocyst lot and pth viability method (see ). The quantities γjp and e1ijp in Eq. , and δjp and e2ijp in Eq. are assumed to be independent normal random variables with means 0, and respective variances σlot12, σe1i, σlot22, and σe2i2, and Tijp is the temperature associated with the ith data set, jth oocyst lot and pth viability method. For each data set i, it is assumed that the variances σe1i2 and σe2i2 are proportional to the variances of the corresponding estimated parameters k and Ctlag. These can be written as (4) σe1i2=S1i2σe12,σe2i2=S2i2σe22, for data set i, S1i2 and S2i2 are the known variances of the posterior means of log(k) and log(Ctlag) from the previously described Bayesian analysis; σe12 and σe22 are the corresponding proportionality constants. Each of the two models (Eqs. ) is fitted using the maximum likelihood method, via the SAS procedure ‘PROC MIXED’ ( ). Formulas for the maximum likelihood estimates of the model parameters are given in the . No significant difference is seen between the intercept parameters a1 and a2, or between c1 and c2 (p=0.26, 0.18, respectively). Moreover, the slope parameters b1 and d1 are not significantly different from the corresponding parameters b2 and d2 (p=0.27, 0.18). Thus the viability determination method is not a significant factor in the above mixed linear model and therefore this factor is not included in the subsequent analysis. The variation among the water types and oocyst strains are accounted for in the random error terms. Therefore, for the pooled study data, Eqs. are modified to yield the following mixed models: (5) ln(k)ij=a+b(1/T)ij+γj+e1ij,j=1,...,m, (6) ln(Ctlag)ij=c+d(1/T)ij+δj+e2ij,j=1,...,m. The estimated fixed model parameters of Eqs. are given by (7) ln(k)=34.9-10200(1/T), (8) ln(Ctlag)=-37.9+11100(1/T). Estimated variances σ^lot12 and σ^lot22 are 0.10 and 0.30, respectively, thus revealing that the variability associated with oocyst lot is relatively higher for Ctlag than for k values. The estimated respective proportionality constants σ^e12and σ^e22 are 4.69 and 1.49. The fraction of the variation in the values of ln(k) explained by variability in temperature, lot and remaining random error are about 0.90, 0.07 and 0.03, respectively. The corresponding estimated fractions for ln(Ctlag) are 0.55, 0.23 and 0.22, respectively. Thus, about 97% of the total variability in the post-lag phase rate constant and about 73% of the variability in lag phase Ct are explained by the fixed factor 1/T and the random factor oocyst lot. The fitted curve for log(k) (Eq. ) and 95% confidence interval (CI), which includes lot and random error variances (see Eq. ), are shown in . The corresponding curves for log(Ctlag) are given in . The figures show that most of the values are within the 95% CI for both parameters. As most of the variability in k and Ctlag are explained by the fixed factor 1/T and the random factor oocyst lot, Eqs. can be used to estimate the Ct value for a given inactivation level and temperature. Consistent with Eqs. , the predicted k and Ctlag values for a given temperature are given by the expressions: (9) k^=exp{a^+b^(1/T)}, (10) CT^lag=exp{c^+d^(1/T)}, where a^, b^, c^ and d^ are 34.9, −10 200, −37.9, and 11 100, respectively. By substituting the above estimated post-lag phase rate constant and lag phase Ct in Eq. , one can predict Ct for a given mean log inactivation level μ. It is important to point out that a fully Bayesian hierarchical model would indeed have been a natural and preferable alternative to the two-step model adapted here. However, the answers from such a combined model were found to be highly sensitive to the prior distributions of the lot variability parameter. Thus the two-step approach previously described was used to analyze the data. The parameters (rate constant and lag phase Ct) and their standard deviations estimated in the first step were further analyzed in the second step to account for the unequal uncertainty in these estimates using a model with heterogeneous error variances. This is, in a sense, equivalent to transporting the posterior distribution of the parameters of interest (slopes and change-points) to the next step; the plots of these posteriors are normal like and can therefore be reasonably approximated by normal distributions. In this sense, the uncertainties in the first step of the two-step approach used are accounted for to a reasonable extent in the second step. 1.4
Estimating a safety factor for Ct

The variations associated with different random effects could be taken into account by including a safety factor in predicting future Ct values. There are three components to the total error variance: (a) variance associated with the mean estimate, (b) variance associated with different oocyst lots, (c) variance associated with the effects of any remaining variables such as experimental and analytical variability. A certain combination of these three components could be used to calculate a safety factor for Ct. Using only (a) means that only the error associated with the mean estimate is included in the safety factor, and that consequently the error associated with the lots or any other variables are disregarded. Incorporating (a) and (b) gives a safety factor which accounts for the error associated with the mean estimate and the variation among different oocyst lots. Adding all three components gives a safety factor for a future Ct. The use of such a safety factor can provide guidance to drinking water utilities. Lot variability is accounted for in the current Long Term 2 Enhanced Surface Water Treatment Rule (LT2 Rule) to inactivate C. parvum oocysts with ozone. Thus a water treatment plant may want to use a similar safety factor. Another reason to use the above safety factor may be to reduce the operating cost of the treatment plant. The upper bound for the Ct model given by Eq. is developed by letting the estimated standard error (SE) of ln(k^) be S1 (square root of V(ln(k^))) and the SE of ln(Ct^lag) be S2. Then an approximate one-sided 100(1−α)% lower confidence limit for ln(k) is ln(k^)-ZαS1, where Zα is the 100(1−α)% cutoff value from a standard normal distribution. Similarly, an approximate one-sided 100(1−α)% upper confidence limit for ln(Ctlag) is ln(Ct^lag)+ZαS2. Let: (11) ln(k^)-ZαS1=L, (12) ln(Ct^lag)+ZαS2=U. Then (13) eL⩽k, (14) Ctlag⩽eU. Substituting the inequalities presented in Eqs. into Eq. for μ gives (15) Ct=[-μ/k]+Ctlag⩽[-μ/eL]+eU and (16) [-μ/eL]+eU=[-μ/exp(ln(k^)-ZαS1)]+exp(ln(Ct^lag)+ZαS2). Thus, (17) Ct⩽[-μ/exp(ln(k^)-ZαS1)]+exp(ln(Ct^lag)+ZαS2) and (18) Ctα=[-μ/exp(34.9-10200(1/T)-ZαS1)]+exp(-37.9+11100(1/T)+ZαS2), where Ctα is the Ct value for any selected α. Thus, for a known temperature T, and mean log inactivation μ, Eq. can be used to obtain an approximate 100(1−α)% upper confidence limit for Ct. To illustrate this approach let T0=1°C and mean log inactivation μ=-2.30. From the , an approximate 90% upper confidence bound for mean Ct is given by (19) Ct0.1=[-μ/exp(34.9-10200(1/T)-Z0.1S1)]+exp(-37.9+11100(1/T)+Z0.1S2)=[2.30/exp{34.9-10200(1/(274))-(1.28)(S1)}]+exp{-37.9+11100(1/(274))+(1.28)(S2)}=39.3mgmin/L. The corresponding values for mean Ct with oocyst lot variability and future Ct are 57.0 and 90.3 mg min/L, respectively (see ). For a given mean log inactivation μ and temperature T, the estimated mean Ct corresponds to Zα=0 in Eq. and is given by (20) Ct=[-μ/exp(34.9-10200(1/T))]+exp(-37.9+11100(1/T)). Note that in Eq. , S1 and S2 are calculated by Eqs. or or presented in the . 1.5
Validation of the Ct model

The data for which lot information was not specified and the cell culture data from are used to validate the model developed in this study. Eqs. were applied to obtain the predicted inactivation curves and corresponding 90% confidence bounds at 1, 10 and 22 °C. The resulting predicted curves are compared to 1 °C data sets from and in , and to 10 and 22 °C data sets from in , respectively. All the data in fall within the safety factor which incorporates the lot variability. Greater data scatter due to analytical variability and lot variability is seen in . Only fourteen of the twenty four data points are within the upper confidence limit which includes the lot variability. 1.6
Conclusions

Bayesian analysis has been used to estimate the lag phase Ct and post-lag phase rate constant k for a delayed Chick–Watson regression model. Monte Carlo samples from the posterior distributions are used to estimate these parameters. A log-linear mixed model is then used to model the estimated post-lag phase rate constants and lag phase Ct values as functions of the fixed factor temperature and the random factor oocyst lot. A formula is developed to estimate the minimum Ct requirement for a given mean log inactivation level of C. parvum oocysts. Thus, by using this two-step procedure one can estimate the minimum required Ct which includes a safety factor, instead of estimating a single estimate for Ct. The present findings suggest that the model developed in this paper can be used to estimate the lag phase Ct, post-lag phase rate constant, and minimum Ct requirement with confidence intervals for a given temperature and target survival ratio of C. parvum oocysts. The model developed in this study presents a two-step approach for water utilities and regulatory agencies to decide on the level of safety needed when developing treatment requirements for the inactivation of C. parvum oocysts with ozone as part of a comprehensive risk analysis incorporating other factors such as the occurrence of oocysts in raw waters, fate of the parasite in other water treatment processes part of multi-barrier systems, epidemiological information, and overall cost analysis. Appendix A The matrix notation for Eqs. is Yn×1=Xn×2β2×1+Ln×mηm×1+en×1, where n is the total number of data points, and m is the number of oocyst lots, Yn×1 is a column vector of all values of the dependent variables ln(k) (or ln(Ctlag)), each row of Xn×2 consists of two values (one is the coefficient of the intercept equal to unity and the second corresponds to the 1/temperature(T) value of a given data set), β2×1 is the column matrix of the (fixed) model parameters (a and b, values in Eq. and c and d, values in Eq. ), ηm×1 is the column vector of unknown random effects parameters γj's (or δj's) corresponding to the different lots, (i,j)th element of Ln×m is 1 for lot j and 0 otherwise, and en×1 is a matrix of error terms. The mean and the variance of en×1 are, respectively, 0n and σeΣn where 0n is the n×n matrix of zeros, Σn is a diagonal n×n matrix with its diagonal values equal to the estimated error variances S1i2 (or S2i2) of ln(k) (or ln(Ctlag)), 1 and its off-diagonal values equal to 0. Moreover, the mean and the variance of ηm×1 are, respectively, 0m and σlot2Im (i.e., E(ηj)=0 and V(ηj)=σlot2 for all j). The variance of Yn×1 is therefore V=L(σlot2Im)L′+σe2∑n. The maximum likelihood estimate (MLE) of β2×1 is (X′V^-1X)-1X′V^-1Y=(β^) and the variance is (X′V^-1X)-1. The MLEs of σlot2 and σe2 are used to estimate V and thus estimate the variance of β2×1. As the mean effect of any lot is zero (i.e., E(ηj)=0), the mean value of yx is given by xβ for a given set of x values described by a vector x. An estimate of mean of yx is xβ^ and an estimate of the variance of mean of yx is x(X′V-1X)-1x. This method of estimating the mean and the variance is applied separately to the mixed linear models given by Eqs. . Let β1 and β2 be the fixed parameters corresponding to the rate constant and lag phase Ct. As E(γj)=E(δj)=0 and E(e1jk)=E(e2jk)=0, a future y1 value for the rate constant (=xβ+γj+e1jk) and a future y2 value for the lag phase Ct (=xβ2+δj+e2jk) can be estimated by only the fixed y^1 factor β and β2. An estimate y^1 of y1 for given x is xβ^1 and an estimate y^2 of y2 for given x is xβ^2V(γj)=σlot12, V(δj)=σlot22, V(e1jk)=f1σe12 and V(e2jk)=f2σe22, where f1 and f2 are unknown values. The average value 0.04 (or 0.57) of the posterior error variance S1i2 (or S2i2) is taken as f1 (or f2). Thus the variance of y1 and y2 are respectively given by V(y1)=Var(xβ1)+σlot12+0.04σe12 and V(y2)=Var(xβ2)+σlot22+0.57σe22. V(y1) is estimated by V(y^1)=x(X′V^1-1X)x′+σlot12+0.04σe12=x(X′V^1-1X)x′+0.10+0.18. Let the estimated standard error (SE) of y^1 be S1 (square root of V(y^1) in Eq. ). Then a one-sided 100(1−α)% lower confidence limit for y1 is y^1-Zα×S1 where Zα is the 100(1−α)% cut-off value from a standard normal distribution. Moreover an estimate of a future single value of y1 for a given x is xβ^1 and an estimate of the variance is S12=x(X′V^1-1X)-1x′+σlot12+0.61σe12. For this study, (X′V^1-1X)-1=[1.487-427.8-427.8123700], β^1=[34.9-10190], σ^lot12=0.10, and (A.1) σ^e12=4.69. An estimate of a future single value of y2 for a given x is xβ^2 and an estimate of the variance is S22=x(X′V^2-1X)-1x′+σ^lot22+σe22. For this study, (X′V^2-1X)-1=[7.97-2303-2303667100], β^2=[-37.911080], σ^lot22=0.30, (A.2) σ^e22=1.49. V(y2) is estimated by V(y^2)=x(X′V^2-1X)x′+σlot22+0.04σe22=x(X′V^1-1X)x′+0.30+0.85. Thus, for given x, an approximate 100(1−α)% one-sided confidence interval can be constructed for a future single value of y. The upper limit for Ct is given by Eq. . In Eq. , S1=[x(X′V^1-1X)-1x′]1/2 and (A.3) S2=[x(X′V^2-1X)-1x′]1/2 for mean Ct and S1=[x(X′V^1-1X)-1x′+σ^lot12]1/2 and (A.4) S2=[x(X′V^2-1X)-1x′+σ^lot22]1/2 for mean Ct plus lot variability, and S1=[x(X′V^1-1X)-1x′+σ^lot12+0.04σ^e12]1/2 and (A.5) S2=[x(X′V^2-1X)-1x′+σ^lot22+0.57σ^e22]1/2, for future Ct.
Example. For a given temperature T0, let x=(1,T0). Then
